item.title: Creating value or delivering value?
item.description: I strongly recommend you to subscribe to Mike Cohn’s newsletter. Content that he shares via the newsletter cannot be found on the website. So, here goes another article from him that may persuade you to go visit his site and subscribe: https://www.mountaingoatsoftware.com/email-tips. Someone told me recently that it is the job of an agile team to create value. I disagree. An agile team’s job is to deliver value. There’s a subtle difference between creating value and delivering it.

item.title: Slicing up the work in Agile
item.description: There are multiples ways to slice the work in a project running in Agile. For example, there is the SPIDR method from Mike Cohn. ﻿ But while Mike Cohn’s method seems more focused on splitting stories, what I found interesting on Gil’s approach to slice, or split, the work, is that it seems to work on a higher level. Read this approach and let me know what you think. To deliver value frequently and adapt to change easily, you must decompose deliverables (stories, features) into small ones.

item.title: Please help! Where do I start learning more about Agile and Scrum?
item.description: At this point I think it is clear how much I appreciate the insights and knowledge of Mike Cohn’s :) Recently I found out about this, also from him: Get Your Free Personalized Guide to Agile. He provides a tool that asks one some questions about Agile, and creates a personalized guide to all previous articles in Agile Mentors, tailored based on the answers given. Here’s an example of my guide: Give it try.

item.title: How many mistakes are we supposed to make?
item.description: This article is from an email newsletter I received from Mike Cohn. I am copying the article to share with those that have not yet found out about that. It seems like we spend a lot of our lives avoiding mistakes. No one wants to make a mistake. And in business, mistakes cost us time and money (often both). But sometimes the effort spent avoiding a mistake can exceed the cost of making the mistake.

item.title: Should we do a mid-sprint review?
item.description: Here’s another piece of advice from Mike Cohn’s, from a newsletter I subscribe. I am no Agile expert, but his advice does make sense. Read it and take your own conclusions: Have you ever been tempted to add a mid-sprint review for your Scrum teams? If so, you’re not alone. I frequently meet teams who have done this. Teams will add a mid-sprint review for any number of many well-intentioned reasons.

item.title: That Henry Ford quote and user centered design
item.description: While waiting for my kids to finish their acrobatics session, I watched this video on Lynda.com, where the instructor talked about the concepts of user-centered design, and after I finished it, I remembered the famous quote attributed to Henry Ford: “If I had asked people what they wanted, they would have said faster horses.” I thought to myself: he was the one that made it possible to many middle-class North Americans to purchase their first automobile; so he might have a point and ignoring customer feedback might indeed leads us to great innovation.

item.title: BPMN: is it too complex or is it that we don't know how to use it
item.description: I attended this webinar, Elements of Business Modeling, from ModernAnalyst, in my agenda for a couple of weeks already, but unfortunately I was only able to attend it when it was starting the Q/A part of it. Fortunately, it had one PDF file resource that proved to be very interesting. The resource, Rethinking BPMN: How to Build GOOD Process Using BPMN, talks about one aspect of BPMN that I have also noticed.

item.title: Kick-Off meetings in Agile projects
item.description: Today I read another article from Mike Cohn, this time, his advice on conducting kick-off meetings in Agile projects. What I couldn’t shake off my mind, after finishing reading it, is how similar that advice resembles what I see in action movies were there is a team of soldiers (or mercenaries) ready to get into action. A short disclaimer: I’ve never served in the army, but if you have, perhaps you can help me correct my understanding.

item.title: Potentially releasable product
item.description: On this article, What Does It Mean to Be Potentially Releasable?, Mike lists 3 characteristics that make up for a “potentially releasable” product: High Quality teams should at least strive to fix bugs that break at least two rules: how often they happen, and how severe they are Well Tested keep in mind that there are levels of testing. For example, testing medical software vs. testing a new online social game requires different approaches Completed The article’s definition says: “any required associated work must be included.

item.title: Alternative view for IIBA knowledge areas diagram
item.description: For those who haven’t seen it yet, here’s one version of the current knowledge areas diagram, as per BABOK® v3.0, depicting the general relationships between each area: The first time I saw it, I took it at face value and didn’t question the way the relationships are showed. It seemed to make sense: Business Analysis Planning & Monitoring is related to Strategy Analysis and Requirements Analysis and Design Definition. This time I am committed to get my CBAP, and I look into this diagram in more detail.

item.title: Mind mapping
item.description: In one of my previous projects, the priority for one of the iterations was to size the effort for different features of the system, in order for business to make an informed decision on which option to select as priority for the next fiscal year. Why were we doing that deserves its own post (or series of). The task seemed daunting: we were tasked to sizing the effort not for one sprint, but for several ones, months in advance.

item.title: What is a customer journey map?
item.description: In this Agile project I was involved, the terms customer journey, journey map, customer map, and any other variation of it were used left and right, and every time, with a different meaning behind. To compound to the confusion of using different terms, the realization of the “map” as stickies on the wall was something else completely. At the time I did some research to try and understand what a customer journey map really is.

item.title: Diagramming tool: draw.io
item.description: In my work laptop, running Windows 7 Enterprise, I have Visio Standard installed. I’ve grown accustomed to a couple of features that make for a productive experience, for example: Shift+mouse wheel, to move sideways Control+mouse wheel, to zoom in and out The alignment guides Layers, to easily create complex diagrams and also easily select elements A vast library of stencils Ability to create your own stencils Ability to export to VSDX and VDX (because I can import those into Gliffy and have my diagram shared easily into a Confluence page) As many of you may know, there is no Visio for MacOS (at least at the time I wrote this).

item.title: EVO - Evolutionary Project Management and Product Development
item.description: A couple of days ago I stumbled on this book: EVO - Evolutionary Project Management & Product Development I started the reading yesterday, so I still don’t have an opinion whether it is good or not, but it does seems promising. Its main premise is that successful projects should be the norm, not the exception. I will come back with another post after I get further into the reading.

item.title: Who is a business analyst
item.description: For the past decade, I have thought about how to best answer this question: who is a business analyst? I believe the answer is not only important in order to explain to others what you do, but also, to ensure any person working on the area can thrive. According to the IIBA glossary, business analysis is defined as: The practice of enabling change in the context of an enterprise by defining needs and recommending solutions that deliver value to stakeholders.

item.title: The lost art of troubleshooting
item.description: Troubleshooting problems seems to be an “art” that is disappearing. Or at least, that is what is seems to me. On my first week as a software tester, back in the day, the team received report that the web site had an issue and it was preventing customers from placing orders. It was a all-hands-on-deck moment and the team got to work to try and reproduce the problem in our testing environment; standard procedure you can say.

item.title: The parable of the two young fish
item.description: Some time ago I stumbled upon this commencement address where I’ve found this fascinating parable of the two young fish: …There are these two young fish swimming along and they happen to meet an older fish swimming the other way, who nods at them and says “Morning, boys. How’s the water?” And the two young fish swim on for a bit, and then eventually one of them looks over at the other and goes “What the hell is water?

item.title: Sustainability in an Agile world
item.description: The text below is from a newsletter I subscribe for. Its author is Gojko Adzic, who also wrote Specification by Example Lots of teams today struggle with scheduling something usually called technical work: system improvements that the team finds important, but nobody actually asked for them. Do too little technical work, and you’re actively damaging the product by slowly turning it into an unmaintainable mess. Do too much of it, and you’re actively damaging the product by delaying important business features.

item.title: Motion versus action
item.description: Motion is when you’re busy doing something, but that task will never produce an outcome by itself. Action, on the other hand, is the type of behavior that will get you a result. If motion doesn’t lead to results, why do we do it? Sometimes we do it because we actually need to plan or learn more. But more often than not, we do it because motion allows us to feel like we’re making progress without running the risk of failure.

item.title: Useful, engaging experiences
item.description: “Usability is always secondary. It’s never the most important thing about an experience. I will accept poor usability if I get what I need, if the total experience is great. I will reject perfect usability if I am not rewarded with a useful, engaging experience.” Donald Norman himself, author of The Design of Everyday Things

item.title: Intent
item.description: A couple of years ago I took a training class on facilitation for business analysts. The trainer often compared the leader-follower model that most organizations follow to what he mentioned as intent-model. His example was a military one: rather than tell the troops how to take control over a specific hill, an intent-based leader would give his/her troops the intent: take over a specific hill. The troops would then use their training and knowledge to achieve the intent.

item.title: An approach to style
item.description: I can’t recall what made me borrow this book from my local library: The Elements of Style, by William Strunk Jr. and E.B. White. On “An approach to style” section I’ve found a couple of interesting rules that struck a chord, as those are things we, business analysts, should have in mind while communicating our work to others. Be clear Clarity is not the prize in writing, nor is it always the principal mark of a good style.
